title: BLTM - Branched Lagrangian Transport Model
subTitle: Branched Lagrangian Transport Model

body:
Model Name (Name of the model, including acronyms):

Branched Lagrangian Transport Model (BLTM)

Contact Name(s) (Person(s) responsible for maintenance of the model):

Julie Kiang (USGS)

Contact Email(s):

jkiang@usgs.gov

Originator(s) (Name(s) of the model developer(s)/author(s)):

David Schoellhamer, and Harvey E. Jobson

Model Version (Version of the model, (i.e., 2.0)):

1.2

Online Link (An organizational website or repository, if available. Multiple allowed):

https://water.usgs.gov/software/BLTM/

Abstract (Description or summary of the model, including its purpose or goals and the type or formalism of the model (e.g., system dynamic, agent based model, machine learning), preferably accompanied by relevant keywords):

BLTM uses Lagrangian calculations that are unconditionally stable and based upon a reference frame that moves at a velocity equal to the mean channel flow velocity. BLTM results are within the accuracy required by most water-quality studies. The BLTM is easily applied to unsteady flows in networks of one-dimensional channels with fixed geometry and tributary inflows. Reaction kinetics for up to 10 constituents are provided in a user-written decay-coefficient subroutine. Postprocessor plot programs improve the utility of the model. The model routes any number of interacting constituents through a system of one-dimensional channels.

Release Date (Date model was originally released (MM, YYYY)):

02, 1995

Last Update (Date of last update (MM, YYYY)):

11, 1996

Organization(s) (Organization(s) that produced, funded, or partnered on the creation of this model):

USGS

Mission Area (USGS mission area with which this model most clearly aligns. https://www.usgs.gov/science/mission-areas):

Water Resources

Resources (Resources (how to use the model, where to download it, related publications, other webpages about the model (in other catalogs), USGS webpage):

Jobson, H.E., and Schoellhamer, D.H., 1993, Users manual for a branched Lagrangian transport model Water-Resources Investigations Report 87-4163, https://doi.org/10.3133/wri874163.

Schoellhamer, D.H., and Jobson, H.E., 1986, Programmers manual for a one-dimensional Lagrangian transport model: U.S. Geological Survey Water-Resources Investigations Report 86-4144, 101 p.

Schoellhamer, D.H., and Jobson, H.E., 1986, Users manual for a one-dimensional Lagrangian transport model: U.S. Geological Survey Water-Resources Investigations Report 86-4145, 95 p.

Jobson, H.E., 1997, Enhancements to the Branched Lagrangian transport modeling system: U.S. Geological Survey Water-Resources Investigations Report 97-4050, 57 p.

Image (URL for an image that best represents the model):

Model Type (process-based model, mathematical model, application model, deterministic model, stochastic model, mechanistic model, empirical model, conceptual model, if other please explain):

Mathematical model

Requirements (All software and/or hardware requirements needed to run the model and replicate any published results):

"BLTM and DAFLOW are written in Fortran 77 with the following extensions: include files and variable program names longer than 6 characters. wdaflow uses the UTIL, ADWDM, and WDM libraries from LIB. A subset of these libraries is provided with the code and may be used instead of the libraries; this subset uses INTEGER*4 and mixed type equivalence. For more information, see System Requirements in LIB. ctplt, cxplt, and flwplt may be implemented with a user-supported Computer Associates DISSPLA library or the LIB libraries GRAPH, UTIL, and STATS."

https://water.usgs.gov/cgi-bin/man_wrdapp?bltm

Structure (Model structure: provide a flow diagram of the model. (e.g. [Growing Degree Days since Jan 1]+[Warm Spells]=[Leaf Out Day of Year] and [Growing Degree Days since Leaf Out Day of Year]+[Warm Spells]=[Bloom Day of Year])):

"The model solves the one-dimensional convective-diffusion equation with reaction kinetics."

https://water.usgs.gov/cgi-bin/man_wrdapp?bltm

Input/Output and Variables (Key input parameters and their values and domain ranges and units (minimum input requirements for model operation and default values, where appropriate); control variables; Key output variables and domain ranges):

"Flow--areas, top widths, and velocities at each grid point are needed for each time step. Data are output in text files. Postprocessor programs are available to produce graphical and tabular summaries."

https://water.usgs.gov/cgi-bin/man_wrdapp?bltm

Conditions (Initial conditions):

"Initial conditions--concentration of each constituent at each grid at time zero. Boundary conditions--concentration of each constituent at upstream junctions and in each tributary during each time step."

https://water.usgs.gov/cgi-bin/man_wrdapp?bltm

webLinks.title: Jobson, H.E., and Schoellhamer, D.H., 1993, Users manual for a branched Lagrangian transport model Water-Resources Investigations Report 87-4163
